page.title: 10WINTERINGHAM OLD SCHOOL 1845
page.content: Mr. Bell, who has lived in the village all his life, started at the national school in 1920. There were only two classrooms,one for the infants and the other for children up to 14. In the infant room the seats were raised in steps. The room had a coal fire and an oil lamp. There were no toys. There were three classes in the large room each doing different lessons. Pupils sat on long forms at sloping desks. They wrote on slates. If you were naughty you got the cane. Only one little stove heated this large room. The toilets, wooden seats with pans underneath, were in the yard. A lorry came to empty them. There were no school dinners. Boys went each week to play football on a nearby field. Mr.Bell was one of the first pupils at the new school opened in 1928.
